text: Anyway-- Savanna's Act *should* be one of the easiest bills Congress passes all year. It's badly needed. Bipartisan. Doesn't cost any additional federal money. We'll see if lawmakers can manage it.

text:
Why is this bill called #SavannasAct?

It's named for Savanna LaFontaine-Greywind, a 22-year-old indigenous woman who was abducted and killed in North Dakota in 2017. She was pregnant and her baby was cut from her womb. Yep.
author: jbendery

text: Savanna's Act would essentially beef up coordination and data collection between all levels of law enforcement -- tribal, local, state and federal -- when it comes to cases involving missing and murdered indigenous women. Data on this is currently terrible and fragmented.

text:
That's... not what this story says. 

I'm a white lady who talked to Native leaders and influencers and let them speak for themselves. Every person quoted in there is Native, and nobody is dismissing that there is also anger out there.
author: jbendery

text: No. I'm saying there's lot of voices out there not being heard and there's much more nuance to this story than a monolithic stream of fury at Warren.
author: jbendery

text: The goal wasn't to find ppl who only liked Warren; I reached out to Native leaders to see what they thought of the news coverage around her DNA test. There was a clear consensus. Is there legit anger out there at Warren? Yes. Is Indian Country collectively outraged? No.
author: jbendery

text: And some Native ppl wondered why Native critics of Warren -- who has been an ally to tribes -- aren't channeling their anger at Trump, whose bullying of Warren and awful treatment of tribes is the core problem. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/elizabeth-warren-dna-test-native-american_us_5c19550fe4b0432554c512bb …
author: jbendery

text: Nearly everyone I talked to lamented that what is happening here is Warren’s personal journey of self-discovery is being being weaponized against Native identity and Native people. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/elizabeth-warren-dna-test-native-american_us_5c19550fe4b0432554c512bb …
author: jbendery

text: I agree with you. It's the cherry picking that's the problem. And in the media coverage of Warren's DNA test + how tribes feel about it, the vast majority of people quoted are the same handful of critics.
author: jbendery

text: Is Warren's DNA test really an issue on the minds of tribal leaders? No. They've got their hands full with serious problems that don't get nearly as much attention.
author: jbendery

text:
There's a diversity of opinions out there. And there is anger. 

The problem is only a handful of Warren critics are being featured in the news. Based on my reporting, this is not a pressing issue in Indian Country. At all.
author: jbendery

text:
Is there legitimate anger at Warren for inflaming complicated issues around Native identity + tribal citizenship vs ancestry, even if unintentional? Yes.

Is Indian Country collectively outraged at Warren over this and focused on it? Absolutely not.
author: jbendery

text:
So where is this idea coming from that tribes are furious with Warren?

An unelected official at Cherokee Nation issued a scathing statement about her DNA test. Multiple ppl told me he was only speaking for himself. His statement is no longer online. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/elizabeth-warren-dna-test-native-american_us_5c19550fe4b0432554c512bb …
author: jbendery

text: Here's Dennis Coker, the principal chief of Delaware’s Lenape Indian Tribe. Does he think Warren has blown her support with tribes because of her DNA test? Nope.
author: jbendery

text: Here's Richard Sneed, principal chief of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. Is he mad at Warren for taking a DNA test to understand her ancestry? Not. At all.
author: jbendery

text: Virtually everyone I talked to -- tribal chiefs, Native politicians, policymakers, advocates, writers -- said they saw nothing wrong with Warren looking into her ancestry. You would never know this from the way mainstream media has covered this. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/elizabeth-warren-dna-test-native-american_us_5c19550fe4b0432554c512bb …
author: jbendery

text:
Missing from so much of the news coverage of Native people being outraged by Elizabeth Warren's DNA test: Native voices.

I asked prominent tribal leaders and Native people about it. Surprise: they said Warren is an ally and this narrative is media fodder. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/elizabeth-warren-dna-test-native-american_us_5c19550fe4b0432554c512bb …

text: Heitkamp's bill sailed through the Senate this month. Unanimous vote. It was expected to sail through the House, too, on the suspension calendar, which expedites votes on bills with broad support. But then it hit a snag. That snag is called Rep. Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.). (8/14)

text: So Heitkamp introduced a bill to try to do something about this. It's called #SavannasAct. It trains and incentivizes law enforcement to better handle cases of murdered and missing indigenous women. I wrote about it here. (7/14)
author: jbendery

text: The level of violence aimed at Native women is so high in Savanna's state that almost everyone in Indian Country -- ~30K American Indians live in ND -- *personally* knows someone who has gone missing or been murdered. That's according to Sen. Heidi Heitkamp (D-N.D.). (6/14)
author: jbendery

text: That was August 2017. Today, Savanna's baby is living with her dad and Savanna's story is part of a horrifying statistic. 84% of Native American women experience violence in their lifetime. In some counties, they are murdered at TEN TIMES the national average. (5/14)
author: jbendery

text: The woman confessed to killing Savanna to kidnap her baby. Her boyfriend admitted dumping bloody towels & his own bloody shoes into an apt building trash bin. Days later, some kayakers found Savanna's body in a river. She was wrapped in plastic and duct tape. (4/14)
author: jbendery

text: Her parents called the police. After reports of suspicious behavior by a couple who lived in the same apt building as Savanna, the police got a search warrant & smashed in the door to their apt. They found the woman who lived there with a newborn. It was Savanna's baby. (3/14)
author: jbendery

text: Once upon a time, there was a beautiful young Native woman named Savanna LaFontaine-Greywind. She lived in Fargo, North Dakota. She was 22 years old. She was eight months pregnant. And then she disappeared. (2/14)
